diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE can present with alopecia, acute pericarditis, a malar rash which may go beyond just maculopapular, and non-erosive arthritis including synovitis.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: Although more commonly associated with chronic symptoms, can present with synovitis and has been associated with pericarditis; rashes and alopecia are less common.

diagnoses.name: Still's Disease (Adult-onset and Juvenile)
diagnoses.rationale: Characterized by high fevers, rash, and arthritis; can involve serositis like pericarditis. Alopecia is less directly associated.

diagnoses.name: Psoriatic Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: Could present with synovitis and skin rash; might have associated conditions leading to alopecia and, less commonly, pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Dermatomyositis
diagnoses.rationale: Can present with a characteristic rash, muscle inflammation, and can have associated alopecia; might have myocarditis or pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.rationale: Can cause a wide range of symptoms including erythema nodosum which might be mistaken as a maculopapular rash, arthritis/synovitis, and less commonly alopecia and acute pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.rationale: Can present with a maculopapular rash especially after administration of ampicillin-related antibiotics; less commonly involves pericarditis or joint symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.rationale: Early Lyme disease can present with erythema migrans (which may appear maculopapular), cardiac involvement including acute pericarditis, and migratory arthritis including synovitis. Alopecia is not primarily associated.

diagnoses.name: Syphilis
diagnoses.rationale: Secondary syphilis can present with a widespread maculopapular rash and less commonly affects the heart or causes arthritis. Alopecia in the form of 'moth-eaten' hair loss is also a feature.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis (e.g., Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis)
diagnoses.rationale: Can cause a wide variety of symptoms including skin rashes, joint pain or synovitis, and cardiac involvement; alopecia can occur due to scalp involvement.

diagnoses: Rheumatoid Arthritis with secondary Sjögren's syndrome
Schizophrenia (in rare cases, can present with acute psychosis and physical symptoms)
Viral Infection (various, including Coxsackievirus and Epstein-Barr virus)
Schizophrenia (for psychosis, if not attributable to a physical illness)
Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) with secondary Sjögren's syndrome
Lymphoproliferative disorders (e.g., Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia, Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma)
Schizophrenia (due to delirium or inflammatory processes altering brain function)
Vasculitis (e.g., Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis, Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis)
Viral infections (e.g., Coxsackie virus, Echovirus, HIV)
Schizophrenia (for psychosis with no clear medical cause)
Schizophrenia (for psychosis if unrelated to other systemic symptoms)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disease commonly presents with symptoms such as discoid rash, synovitis, leukopenia, seizures, and acute pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: Though more commonly associated with joint problems, in severe cases, it can cause systemic issues including pericarditis and can contribute to leukopenia.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.rationale: This condition overlaps with several autoimmune disorders and can present with symptoms reminiscent of SLE, including synovitis, rash, and occasionally seizures.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Sclerosis (Scleroderma)
diagnoses.rationale: Systemic sclerosis can lead to inflammatory symptoms including synovitis, and can have cardiac involvement, although seizures and discoid rash are less common.

diagnoses.name: Sjogren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily affecting exocrine glands, Sjogren's can have systemic manifestations including arthritis (synovitis) and hematologic abnormalities (leukopenia). Neurological manifestations can occasionally include seizures.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Nephritis
diagnoses.rationale: This complication of SLE could indirectly cause seizures due to renal impairment, and directly cause acute pericarditis, discoid rash, leukopenia, and synovitis as part of the systemic lupus presentation.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Endocarditis
diagnoses.rationale: Though a less common presentation, infectious endocarditis can occasionally cause rheumatologic manifestations similar to synovitis, and in severe cases, leukopenia. It primarily affects the heart but does not usually directly cause seizures or rash.

diagnoses.name: Drug-Induced Lupus
diagnoses.rationale: This condition mimics SLE and can cause similar symptoms including pericarditis, leukopenia, and rash. Seizures are rare but have been reported.

diagnoses.name: Vasculitis
diagnoses.rationale: Certain types of vasculitis could theoretically cause a wide range of symptoms, including those affecting the skin, blood cells (leukopenia), and occasionally seizures. Cardiovascular involvement could mimic pericarditis.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: This autoimmune disorder can cause a wide variety of symptoms depending on the organ systems involved, potentially including those listed, albeit seizures and rash are more indirectly related through thrombotic events and lupus-like symptoms respectively.

diagnoses: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (e.g., Crohn's Disease, Ulcerative Colitis)
Blepharospasm (part of a neurological condition such as Parkinson's disease)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can cause inflammation and pain in any part of your body. It's characterized by periods of illness, called flares, and periods of wellness, or remission.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: A chronic inflammatory disorder affecting many joints, including those in the hands and feet. The immune system attacks the body's own tissues, leading to joint pain and damage.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An immune system disorder characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth. The disease can also affect other parts of the body, including the skin, joints, lungs, kidneys, and nerves.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Myeloma
diagnoses.description: A cancer of plasma cells, a type of white blood cell in bone marrow. It causes cancer cells to accumulate in the bone marrow, where they crowd out healthy blood cells. It might cause increased levels of immunoglobulins in the blood.

diagnoses.name: Primary Biliary Cholangitis
diagnoses.description: A chronic disease that destroys bile ducts in the liver. Symptoms include fatigue, itching and dry eyes, and mouth. It can lead to cirrhosis and liver failure.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.description: An immune reaction to eating gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye. Over time, the immune response to eating gluten damages the small intestine's lining and prevents absorption of some nutrients.

diagnoses.name: Interstitial Cystitis
diagnoses.description: A chronic condition causing bladder pressure, bladder pain and sometimes pelvic pain. The condition is a part of a spectrum of diseases known as painful bladder syndrome.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complicated disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition. Cognitive impairment and worsening symptoms after exertion are common.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory, and mood issues. It can amplify painful sensations by affecting the way your brain processes pain signals.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: A tick-borne illness caused by the bacterium Borrelia burgdorferi. It often starts with a rash and can be accompanied by fever, headache, and fatigue. If untreated, it can spread to joints, the heart, and the nervous system.

diagnoses: Inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, Ulcerative colitis)
Autoimmune diseases (e.g., Rheumatoid arthritis, Sjögren's syndrome)

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by intense, throbbing pain often accompanied by nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound. Mood lability can be a related symptom due to the stress and discomfort caused by migraine attacks.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.description: A chronic condition where stomach acid frequently flows back into the tube connecting your mouth and stomach (esophagus). This backwash (acid reflux) can irritate the lining of your esophagus. Although not directly related to the other symptoms, it's a significant condition to consider with reported gastroesophageal reflux.

diagnoses.name: Urinary Tract Infection (UTI)
diagnoses.description: An infection in any part of the urinary system, kidneys, bladder, or urethra. UTIs are more common in females but can affect anyone. Symptoms include a strong, persistent urge to urinate, a burning sensation when urinating, and cloudy urine.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough of certain crucial hormones. Hypothyroidism may not directly cause headaches but can be associated with a general feeling of being unwell, which may contribute to headaches. It can cause delayed puberty and mood changes as well.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: A hormonal disorder common among women of reproductive age. Women with PCOS may have infrequent or prolonged menstrual periods or excess male hormone (androgen) levels. The ovaries may develop numerous small collections of fluid (follicles) and fail to regularly release eggs. It can lead to mood lability and delayed puberty.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease (CKD)
diagnoses.description: A long-term condition where the kidneys don't work as well as they should. It's associated with urinary symptoms and can impact the body's mineral balance, contributing to issues like delayed puberty.

diagnoses.name: Gastrointestinal Dysmotility
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the muscles of the gastrointestinal tract do not work as they should. This could link gastroesophageal reflux with other systemic symptoms but is less directly related to urinary tract infections or delayed puberty.

diagnoses.name: Depression
diagnoses.description: A mood disorder that causes a persistent feeling of sadness and loss of interest. It can manifest with physical symptoms such as headaches and changes in appetite that may affect gastroesophageal reflux. Mood lability is a core symptom of depression.

diagnoses.name: Cushing's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition that occurs from exposure to high cortisol levels for a long time. The symptoms may include weight gain, fatty deposit between the shoulders (buffalo hump), purple stretch marks, and irregular menstruation, which could indirectly relate to the symptoms described.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A group of diseases that result in too much sugar in the blood (high blood glucose). While not directly causing all the listed symptoms, complications or poorly managed diabetes can lead to systemic symptoms that may indirectly relate to the described symptom profile.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.reasoning: Sensory neuropathies are common in long-standing diabetes due to diabetic neuropathy. Diabetes can also lead to an increased risk of urinary tract infections.

diagnoses.name: Paraneoplastic Syndromes
diagnoses.reasoning: Certain cancers can lead to paraneoplastic syndromes, where polycythemia is observed. Sensory neuropathies and vascular anomalies can also be part of the syndromic presentation.

diagnoses.name: Polycythemia Vera
diagnoses.reasoning: A myeloproliferative disorder that leads to increased red blood cell production. It can cause bloating and has been associated with an increased risk of vascular anomalies due to increased blood viscosity.

diagnoses.name: Renal Cell Carcinoma
diagnoses.reasoning: Can cause polycythemia due to erythropoietin production. It may also lead to sensory neuropathies as a paraneoplastic syndrome and might cause or be associated with urinary tract infections secondary to kidney involvement.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Myeloma
diagnoses.reasoning: This condition can present with sensory neuropathies due to nerve damage caused by the accumulation of monoclonal proteins. It can also lead to an increased risk of infections, including urinary tract infections.

diagnoses.name: Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.reasoning: A systemic autoimmune disease that can cause vascular anomalies and has been associated with polycythemia in some cases. It can lead to sensory neuropathies and increase the risk of urinary tract infections due to immune dysfunction.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.reasoning: An autoimmune disease that primarily affects exocrine glands but can cause peripheral neuropathy. Additionally, it can increase the risk of urinary tract infections.

diagnoses.name: Fabry Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: A rare genetic disorder that can cause vascular anomalies due to glycolipid accumulation in the blood vessels. It can also lead to sensory neuropathies.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: Can lead to sensory neuropathies, an increased risk of urinary tract infections, and a contributor to polycythemia due to decreased erythropoietin clearance or production.

diagnoses.name: Von Hippel-Lindau Disease
diagnoses.reasoning: A genetic disorder that can cause vascular tumors (hemangioblastomas) and renal cell carcinoma, leading to sensory neuropathies, polycythemia, and an increased risk of urinary tract infections.

diagnoses: Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) - considering the bronchitis aspect
Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) - considering the complaint of endometriosis and its possible differential diagnoses

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough of certain crucial hormones, potentially causing constipation and mood lability.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An immune system disorder characterized by dry eyes and mouth, which might also cause lymphadenitis and hypersensitivity reactions.

diagnoses.name: Lupus
diagnoses.description: A systemic autoimmune disease that can affect any part of the body, leading to widespread inflammation and tissue damage in the affected organs. It can cause a variety of symptoms including hypersensitivity reactions and lymphadenitis.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Rhinitis
diagnoses.description: An allergic reaction causing sneezing, runny or blocked nose, and irritated eyes. It may also lead to mood changes due to discomfort and sleep disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Gastrointestinal Disorders
diagnoses.description: Various conditions affecting the gastrointestinal tract, such as irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) or inflammatory bowel diseases (IBD). These disorders can cause constipation.

diagnoses.name: Non-Hodgkin Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that originates in your lymphatic system, causing lymphadenitis, mood lability, and could potentially lead to hypersensitivity reactions due to immune system involvement.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A long-term condition that causes pain all over the body, and can also lead to mood lability. Though not directly related to constipation or eye irritation, individuals with fibromyalgia may experience a wide range of symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Depression
diagnoses.description: A mood disorder causing a persistent feeling of sadness and loss of interest. It can lead to constipation and mood lability. Depression might also decrease the patient's tolerance to various physical symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Allergies
diagnoses.description: Hypersensitivity of the immune system to something in the environment that usually causes little or no reaction in most people. Can cause irritated eyes and lymphadenitis in severe reactions.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.description: A mental health disorder characterized by feelings of worry, anxiety, or fear that are strong enough to interfere with one's daily activities. Symptoms can include mood lability and hypersensitivity reactions.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Rhinosinusitis
diagnoses.description: A condition characterized by inflammation of the paranasal sinuses lasting for a long duration. It can lead to dysosmia, fibrotic changes in sinus tissues, and can indirectly affect mood and physical sensitivities due to chronic discomfort.

diagnoses.name: Autoimmune Disorders
diagnoses.description: Diseases like Sjögren's syndrome or systemic lupus erythematosus can manifest with a wide range of symptoms including fibrosis in various tissues, laryngitis, and mood lability due to the systemic nature of the inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory and mood issues. Patients may report physical sensitivities and mood lability, though dysosmia and laryngitis are less commonly associated.

diagnoses.name: Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic, progressive lung disease that results in scarring (fibrosis) of the lungs. While its primary symptoms are respiratory, systemic effects can potentially lead to symptoms like dysosmia and laryngitis.

diagnoses.name: Sarcoidosis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease that can affect multiple organs. Lung and lymph node involvement can lead to fibrosis. Neurosarcoidosis can affect the nervous system, potentially causing dysosmia and mood lability.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Chemical Sensitivity
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by severe physical symptoms from exposure to certain chemicals. Symptoms can include mood lability, physical sensitivities, and dysosmia. It is a controversial diagnosis and not recognized universally.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition. Symptoms can include physical sensitivities and mood changes, but dysosmia and laryngitis are not commonly reported.

diagnoses.name: Environmental Allergies
diagnoses.description: Allergic reactions to environmental substances can cause symptoms like dysosmia and laryngitis. Chronic exposure can lead to mood changes and physical sensitivities due to the ongoing discomfort.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.description: A digestive disorder where stomach acid flows back into the esophagus, causing a variety of symptoms. Chronic GERD can lead to laryngitis and has been linked to fibrosis in severe cases. Mood lability and physical sensitivities can arise from the chronic discomfort.

diagnoses.name: Psychosomatic Disorder
diagnoses.description: A condition where psychological stress causes physical symptoms without a physical disease. Can include a broad range of symptoms such as mood lability, physical sensitivities, and dysosmia, driven by psychological factors.

diagnoses.name: Generalized Anxiety Disorder
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by chronic, exaggerated worrying and anxiety about everyday life. Can sometimes present with physical symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that starts in cells that are part of the body's immune system. Symptoms can include enlarged lymph nodes, fatigue, and night sweats.

diagnoses.name: Infectious Mononucleosis
diagnoses.description: Often called mono, it's an infection usually caused by the Epstein-Barr virus. Symptoms can include fatigue, sore throat, fever, and swollen lymph nodes.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition that can cause multiple symptoms. It’s frequently characterized by intense, debilitating headaches. Symptoms can include nausea, vomiting, difficulty speaking, numbness or tingling, and sensitivity to light and sound.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.description: Human immunodeficiency virus, a virus that can lead to Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome, a condition in humans in which progressive failure of the immune system allows life-threatening opportunistic infections and cancers to thrive.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect any part of the body, including the nervous system, resulting in a wide range of symptoms including fatigue, headaches, swollen joints, and fever.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A disorder characterized by widespread musculoskeletal pain accompanied by fatigue, sleep, memory and mood issues. It can also lead to heightened pain response to pressure.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorder
diagnoses.description: A mental health disorder characterized by feelings of worry, anxiety, or fear that are strong enough to interfere with one's daily activities.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Fatigue Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A complex disorder characterized by extreme fatigue that can't be explained by any underlying medical condition. The fatigue worsens with physical or mental activity but doesn't improve with rest.

diagnoses.name: Giant Cell Arteritis
diagnoses.description: An inflammatory disease characterized by the inflammation of the lining of the arteries. Symptoms can include headaches, jaw pain, vision problems, and scalp tenderness.

diagnoses.name: Hemorrhoids
diagnoses.description: Swollen and inflamed veins in the rectum and anus that cause discomfort and bleeding.

diagnoses.name: Otitis Media
diagnoses.description: An infection of the air-filled space behind the eardrum that can cause earache and fever.

diagnoses.name: Blepharospasm
diagnoses.description: A condition causing involuntary tight closure of the eyelids.

diagnoses.name: Leukocytosis
diagnoses.description: An increase in the number of white blood cells in the blood, often indicating an infection or other disease.

diagnoses.name: Common Cold
diagnoses.description: A viral infectious disease of the upper respiratory tract which primarily affects the nose. It may increase the risk of developing secondary infections leading to conditions like Otitis Media.

diagnoses.name: Influenza
diagnoses.description: A viral infection that attacks your respiratory system. Influenza symptoms can include fever, aching muscles, and congestion.

diagnoses.name: Allergic Rhinitis
diagnoses.description: An allergic response causing itchy, watery eyes, sneezing, and other similar symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Sinusitis
diagnoses.description: Inflammation of the sinus cavities often caused by infection, resulting in congestion, headache, and facial pain.

diagnoses.name: Upper Respiratory Infection
diagnoses.description: Infections in the throat, sinuses, larynx, or bronchi, which may cause symptoms such as congestion and cough.

diagnoses.name: Anemia
diagnoses.description: A condition in which you lack enough healthy red blood cells to carry adequate oxygen to your body's tissues. Can be related indirectly due to chronic disease or infection.

diagnoses.name: Vocal cord paralysis
diagnoses.description: A condition that occurs when nerve impulses to your voice box (larynx) are disrupted, resulting in paralysis of the muscle. Patients may experience laryngitis-like symptoms due to inability to properly use the vocal cords.

diagnoses.name: Multiple system atrophy
diagnoses.description: A rare degenerative neurological disorder affecting your body's involuntary functions, including blood pressure, heart rate, and bladder function, potentially explaining dysautonomias.

diagnoses.name: Ehlers-Danlos syndromes
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders that affect connective tissues supporting the skin, bones, blood vessels, and many other organs and tissues. Often associated with aneurysms due to the weakness in the connective tissue.

diagnoses.name: Familial dysautonomia
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that affects the development and survival of certain nerve cells. It primarily impacts the autonomic nervous system, leading to dysautonomias.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barré syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves, leading to muscle weakness and sometimes paralysis, including sensory neuropathies.

diagnoses.name: Chronic inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy
diagnoses.description: A neurological disorder characterized by progressive weakness and impaired sensory function in the legs and arms, indicative of sensory neuropathies.

diagnoses.name: Marfan syndrome
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that affects the body’s connective tissue, potentially leading to aneurysms and other complications in various parts of the body.

diagnoses.name: Peripheral neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A result of damage to your peripheral nerves, often causing weakness, numbness, and pain, usually in your hands and feet, but can also affect other areas and functions, including sensory perception.

diagnoses.name: Laryngeal cancer
diagnoses.description: Cancer that occurs in the larynx, or voice box, which can lead to symptoms similar to laryngitis due to tumor growth affecting voice box function.

diagnoses.name: Autonomic neuropathy
diagnoses.description: A group of symptoms that occur when there is damage to nerves that regulate nonvoluntary body functions including heart rate, blood pressure, and digestion, which encompasses aspects of dysautonomias.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which your thyroid gland doesn't produce enough of certain crucial hormones. Hypothyroidism may not cause noticeable symptoms in the early stages, but over time, untreated hypothyroidism can cause a number of health problems, such as obesity, joint pain, infertility, and heart disease.

diagnoses.name: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome (PCOS)
diagnoses.description: A hormonal disorder common among women of reproductive age. Women with PCOS may have infrequent or prolonged menstrual periods or excess male hormone (androgen) levels. The ovaries may develop numerous small collections of fluid (follicles) and fail to regularly release eggs.

diagnoses.name: Cushing's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A condition that occurs from exposure to high cortisol levels for a long time. The most common cause is the use of steroid medication, with other causes including a pituitary gland tumor resulting in high levels of ACTH, and a tumor in the adrenal glands. Symptoms may include upper body obesity, round face, increased fat around the neck, and thinning arms and legs.

diagnoses.name: Metabolic Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A cluster of conditions that occur together, increasing your risk of heart disease, stroke, and type 2 diabetes. These conditions include increased blood pressure, high blood sugar, excess body fat around the waist, and abnormal cholesterol or triglyceride levels.

diagnoses.name: Hypertension
diagnoses.description: Also known as high blood pressure, a condition in which the force of the blood against the artery walls is too high. Usually hypertension is defined as blood pressure above 140/90, and is considered severe if the pressure is above 180/120.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A group of diseases that result in too much sugar in the blood (high blood glucose). Type 2 diabetes, which is more common, involves insulin resistance or a reduced response to insulin, often associated with weight gain.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Otitis Media
diagnoses.description: Long-standing infections of the middle ear with varying degrees of inflammation that can result in damage to the ear’s structures. Frequent episodes of acute otitis media can develop into chronic otitis media.

diagnoses.name: Acromegaly
diagnoses.description: A hormonal disorder that develops when your pituitary gland produces too much growth hormone during adulthood. This syndrome can lead to gradual changes in facial features, such as a protruding lower jaw and brow bone, enlarged nose, and increased size of hands and feet. Weight gain and skin changes can also be symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Rosacea
diagnoses.description: A common skin condition that causes blushing or flushing and visible blood vessels in your face. It may also produce small, red, pus-filled bumps. These signs and symptoms may flare up for weeks to months and then go away for a while. Rosacea can be mistaken for acne, other skin problems, or natural ruddiness.

diagnoses.name: Marfan Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A genetic disorder that affects the body’s connective tissue. Connective tissue holds all the body’s cells, organs and tissue together. It also plays an important role in helping the body grow and develop properly. Features of the disorder are most often found in the heart, blood vessels, bones, joints, and eyes. Some Marfan features – for example, aortic enlargement (an abnormal widening of the large blood vessel that distributes blood from the heart to the rest of the body) – can be life-threatening.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy
diagnoses.description: A neurological disorder that causes progressive weakness and impaired sensory function in the legs and arms.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Myeloma
diagnoses.description: A type of cancer that forms in a type of white blood cell called a plasma cell, which can cause increased immunoglobulins, bone pain, and complications leading to malabsorption.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissue, potentially causing a wide array of symptoms including joint pain and dysfunction in multiple organs.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder that primarily affects joints but can also cause systemic symptoms, including increased immunoglobulins.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease characterized by dry eyes and dry mouth, which can also cause systemic symptoms, including joint pain and dysfunction of various organs.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland doesn't produce enough thyroid hormone, leading to symptoms like fatigue, cold intolerance (hypothermia), and potentially contributing to malabsorption.

diagnoses.name: Celiac Disease
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disorder where the ingestion of gluten leads to damage in the small intestine, causing symptoms like malabsorption and chronic pain, including back pain.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Pancreatitis
diagnoses.description: Long-standing inflammation of the pancreas that alters its normal structure and functions. It can cause malabsorption and back pain due to the proximity of the pancreas to the spine.

diagnoses.name: Whipple's Disease
diagnoses.description: A rare bacterial infection that can affect the joint, causing chronic pain, malabsorption due to its primary effect on the small intestine, and systemic symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Amyloidosis
diagnoses.description: A rare disease that occurs when a substance called amyloid builds up in your organs, leading to various symptoms including malabsorption, organ dysfunction, and increased immunoglobulins.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that often features symptoms such as dry eyes, dry mouth, and can also affect other organs of the body.

diagnoses.name: Diabetes Mellitus
diagnoses.description: A metabolic disorder that can cause abnormal electrolyte levels, periodontal disease, and is associated with a higher rate of anxiety disorders.

diagnoses.name: Hyperparathyroidism
diagnoses.description: A condition involving the overproduction of parathyroid hormone, leading to abnormal calcium levels, which can manifest as abnormal electrolyte levels, and contribute to interstitial cystitis symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Chronic Kidney Disease
diagnoses.description: This condition can lead to abnormal electrolyte levels, can exacerbate periodontal disease due to changes in calcium and phosphorus metabolism, and is associated with increased rates of anxiety.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.description: This autoimmune disease might not directly cause all these symptoms but has been associated with periodontal disease, dry eyes due to secondary Sjögren's syndrome, and can exacerbate anxiety.

diagnoses.name: Fibromyalgia
diagnoses.description: A long-term condition that causes pain all over the body and can be associated with anxiety. Some patients also report symptoms similar to interstitial cystitis.

diagnoses.name: Anxiety Disorders
diagnoses.description: While not a direct cause of the other symptoms, severe or chronic anxiety can exacerbate or lead to the perception of various physical symptoms, such as dry eyes (due to decreased blinking), and can worsen the experience of interstitial cystitis.

diagnoses.name: Hypothyroidism
diagnoses.description: Low thyroid function can lead to a variety of symptoms including dry eyes, anxiety, and can affect oral health, indirectly contributing to periodontal disease.

diagnoses.name: Primary Biliary Cholangitis
diagnoses.description: This chronic disease affects the liver's ability to eliminate bile, leading to dry eyes and mouth as part of sicca syndrome, and can be associated with abnormal electrolytes.

diagnoses.name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
diagnoses.description: While primarily affecting the digestive system, GERD has been associated with extraesophageal symptoms including oral health issues, and the stress it causes can exacerbate anxiety and indirectly affect other symptoms.

diagnoses: Bleeding Disorders, such as Von Willebrand Disease
Sleep Disorders, including Obstructive Sleep Apnea
Inflammatory Bowel Disease (Crohn's disease and Ulcerative Colitis)
Eating Disorders (e.g., Anorexia Nervosa, Bulimia Nervosa)

symptoms: dyspnea with normal pulmonary function tests
diagnoses: Eosinophilic Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (formerly Churg-Strauss Syndrome)
Drug Reaction with Eosinophilia and Systemic Symptoms (DRESS Syndrome)
Asthma exacerbation triggered by an allergic reaction
Acute abdominal conditions (e.g., appendicitis, ectopic pregnancy, intestinal obstruction)
Anaphylaxis (in severe cases of allergic reaction)
Inflammatory bowel disease (e.g., Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis)
Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD, related to wheezing)

diagnoses.name: Allergic reactions
diagnoses.description: An exaggerated response of the immune system to a substance that is ordinarily harmless, which can cause angioedema, rhinorrhea, pruritis, and flushing.

diagnoses.name: Anaphylaxis
diagnoses.description: A severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that can lead to rapid onset of flushing, angioedema, and pruritis.

diagnoses.name: Mast cell activation syndromes (MCAS)
diagnoses.description: A group of disorders characterized by an excessive release of mast cell mediators, leading to symptoms such as flushing, pruritis, and anaphylaxis.

diagnoses.name: Hereditary angioedema
diagnoses.description: A rare genetic condition causing recurring attacks of angioedema, often accompanied by pruritis, but not usually associated with hives or itching.

diagnoses.name: Chronic urticaria
diagnoses.description: A condition where hives or urticaria last for more than six weeks, often accompanied by pruritis and flushing.

diagnoses.name: Carbohydrate-deficient glycoprotein syndrome
diagnoses.description: A group of inherited disorders that affect the process of glycosylation, the addition of sugar chains to proteins, leading to a wide range of symptoms, including gastrointestinal issues which might indirectly cause or exacerbate incontinence.

diagnoses.name: Neuroendocrine tumors
diagnoses.description: Tumors arising from the neuroendocrine cells, capable of producing a variety of symptoms such as flushing and diarrhea due to hormone secretion, which might contribute to incontinence.

diagnoses.name: Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease that can affect several systems in the body, including the skin, presenting symptoms like flushing and potentially renal involvement that could lead to incontinence.

diagnoses.name: Multiple sclerosis (MS)
diagnoses.description: A chronic illness of the central nervous system that can lead to bladder dysfunction, manifesting as incontinence, amidst other neurological symptoms.

diagnoses.name: Medication side effects
diagnoses.description: Various medications can cause side effects including incontinence, angioedema, pruritis, flushing, and rhinorrhea, especially if there is an allergic or adverse reaction to the medication.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with aura
diagnoses.description: A type of headache characterized by neurological phenomena (aura) that precedes the actual headache. Symptoms can include visual disturbances, vertigo, and paresthesia.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune disease affecting the central nervous system, leading to numerous neurological symptoms including vision problems, paresthesia, and balance issues.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack
diagnoses.description: Often referred to as a 'mini-stroke,' it temporarily blocks blood flow to the brain, causing various neurological symptoms, including dizziness, speech problems, and visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Vertebrobasilar Insufficiency
diagnoses.description: A condition resulting from reduced blood flow in the arteries at the back of the neck, leading to symptoms like dizziness, double vision, and balance problems.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Abnormal cell growth in the brain can pressure brain tissue and nerves, leading to symptoms such as vision problems, vertigo, and paresthesia.

diagnoses.name: Meniere's Disease
diagnoses.description: A disorder of the inner ear causing severe dizziness (vertigo), ringing in the ears (tinnitus), hearing loss, and a feeling of fullness or congestion in the ear.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: Occurs when blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients, leading to symptoms like paralysis, speech difficulties, and vision problems.

A central nervous system disorder in which brain activity becomes abnormal, causing seizures or periods of unusual behavior, sensations, and sometimes loss of awareness. Visual symptoms and sensory disturbances may occur.

diagnoses.name: Vitamin B12 Deficiency
diagnoses.description: Lack of B12 can lead to neurological issues, including paresthesia, balance problems, and visual disturbances due to its role in nerve health and blood formation.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: Infectious disease caused by the Borrelia bacterium, spread by ticks. Neurological complications can include facial palsy, neuropathy, and meningitis, leading to a variety of symptoms such as paresthesia and visual disturbances.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical condition that occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Symptoms can include numbness, difficulty speaking (aphasia), and difficulty swallowing (dysphagia).

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: An autoimmune disease that affects the brain and spinal cord, leading to various neurological symptoms including numbness, paresthesia, and in some cases, dysphagia.

diagnoses.name: Migraine with Aura
diagnoses.description: A type of migraine that involves visual disturbances (scotoma) and other neurological symptoms such as sensory disturbances (paresthesia) before the onset of headache.

diagnoses.name: Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA)
diagnoses.description: Often called a mini-stroke, a TIA produces similar symptoms to a stroke, like aphasia and numbness, but usually lasts only a few minutes and causes no permanent damage.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: Abnormal growth of cells within the brain that can disrupt normal brain function, leading to symptoms such as dysphagia, aphasia, and sometimes paresthesia or numbness depending on the location of the tumor.

diagnoses.name: Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS)
diagnoses.description: A type of motor neuron disease that affects voluntary muscle movement, which can lead to symptoms such as dysphagia. As the disease progresses, it can also cause numb sensations.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which the body's immune system attacks the nerves, leading to symptoms such as paresthesia, numbness, and in advanced stages, difficulty swallowing.

diagnoses.name: Myasthenia Gravis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune neuromuscular disease that causes weakness in the skeletal muscles, which can cause dysphagia and may lead to numbness or paresthesia sensations.

diagnoses.name: Lyme Disease
diagnoses.description: Infectious disease caused by Borrelia bacteria, transmitted to humans through the bite of infected black-legged ticks. It can cause neurological symptoms like facial palsy (which can affect swallowing), numbness, and paresthesia.

diagnoses.name: Brain Abscess
diagnoses.description: A collection of pus that develops in the brain due to an infection. Symptoms can include altered mental status, vision problems such as scotomas, aphasia, and in some cases, numbness or paresthesia depending on the location of the abscess.

diagnoses.name: Migraine
diagnoses.description: A neurological condition that can cause multiple symptoms including severe headaches, nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and sound. Paresthesia and numbness are common aura symptoms before the headache phase.

diagnoses.name: Stroke
diagnoses.description: A medical condition that occurs when the blood supply to part of the brain is interrupted or reduced, preventing brain tissue from getting oxygen and nutrients. Symptoms can include sudden numbness, weakness, especially on one side of the body, confusion, trouble speaking, understanding speech, headache, and altered consciousness.

diagnoses.name: Multiple Sclerosis
diagnoses.description: A chronic autoimmune demyelinating disease of the central nervous system. It can cause a wide range of symptoms, including fatigue, difficulty walking, numbness or weakness, muscle spasms, and issues with coordination and balance.

diagnoses.name: Guillain-Barre Syndrome
diagnoses.description: A rare disorder in which your body's immune system attacks your nerves. Weakness and tingling in your extremities are usually the first symptoms. These sensations can quickly spread, eventually paralyzing your whole body.

diagnoses.name: Dehydration
diagnoses.description: A condition that occurs when you use or lose more fluid than you take in, and your body doesn't have enough water and other fluids to carry out its normal functions. Can cause extreme thirst, vomiting, and serious complications.

diagnoses.name: Diabetic Ketoacidosis
diagnoses.description: A serious diabetes complication where the body produces excess blood acids (ketones). Symptoms may include vomiting, abdominal pain, weakness, and numbness.

diagnoses.name: Meningitis
diagnoses.description: An acute inflammation of the protective membranes covering the brain and spinal cord, known collectively as the meninges. The most common symptoms are fever, headache, and neck stiffness.

diagnoses.name: Intoxication
diagnoses.description: Exposure to chemical, physical, or biological agents that can cause harmful effects to the body. Symptoms can include headache, vomiting, numbness, and other neurological impairments.

diagnoses.name: Brain Tumor
diagnoses.description: A mass or growth of abnormal cells in your brain. Many different types of brain tumors exist. Symptoms can include headaches that may be severe and worsen, vomiting, weakness or loss of sensation in limbs, and seizures.

diagnoses.name: Thyroid Storm
diagnoses.description: A rare but severe and potentially life-threatening complication of hyperthyroidism. Symptoms include fever, vomiting, increased heart rate, confusion, and weakness.

diagnoses: Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly known as Wegener's granulomatosis)
Vasculitis (e.g., Henoch-Schönlein purpura, Granulomatosis with polyangiitis)
Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) with secondary Sjögren's syndrome
Epilepsy (secondary to CNS lupus or vasculitis)
Viral encephalitis (as a differential for seizures)
Rheumatoid arthritis (with secondary Sjogren's syndrome for oral ulcers)
Chilblains Lupus (A form of Cutaneous Lupus Erythematosus)
Viral hemorrhagic fevers (e.g., Ebola, Marburg, Yellow fever)
Vasculitis (e.g., Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis, Microscopic Polyangiitis)
Severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2) infection
Granulomatosis with Polyangiitis (formerly known as Wegener's Granulomatosis)
Epilepsy (due to the inclusion of seizures in symptoms)
Epilepsy (seizures in the context of underlying systemic conditions)
Evans Syndrome (Autoimmune hemolytic anemia with thrombocytopenia)

diagnoses.name: Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE)
diagnoses.rationale: SLE can present with a wide range of symptoms, including psychosis (neuropsychiatric SLE), hemolytic anemia, synovitis (inflammation of synovial joints), leukopenia, and oral ulcers.

diagnoses.name: Rheumatoid Arthritis
diagnoses.rationale: Though primarily affecting joints, severe cases can present with systemic symptoms such as hemolytic anemia and oral ulcers. Leukopenia and psychosis are rarer but possible in the context of systemic involvement or medication side effects.

diagnoses.name: Sjögren's Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: Known for causing dry eyes and dry mouth, this syndrome can also lead to systemic issues such as hemolytic anemia and leukopenia. Oral ulcers are common, and joint involvement can lead to synovitis.

diagnoses.name: Behçet's Disease
diagnoses.rationale: This is a multisystem inflammatory disorder characterized by oral ulcers, genital ulcers, ocular inflammation, and can also involve psychiatric symptoms, hemolytic anemia, and leukopenia.

diagnoses.name: Antiphospholipid Syndrome
diagnoses.rationale: While primarily associated with thrombotic events, antiphospholipid syndrome can cause hemolytic anemia and, less commonly, cerebral involvement leading to psychiatric symptoms. Leukopenia and oral ulcers may also be present.

diagnoses.name: HIV/AIDS
diagnoses.rationale: HIV infection can lead to a variety of symptoms including leukopenia, oral ulcers, and, in advanced stages, psychosis due to opportunistic infections or malignancies. Hemolytic anemia can occur as a complication of infection or treatment.

diagnoses.name: Systemic Vasculitis
diagnoses.rationale: Various forms of vasculitis can result in hemolytic anemia, oral ulcers, and leukopenia. Depending on the severity and areas of involvement, patients may exhibit psychiatric symptoms and joint pain due to synovitis.

diagnoses.name: Mixed Connective Tissue Disease
diagnoses.rationale: This disease shares features of systemic lupus erythematosus, scleroderma, and polymyositis, including hemolytic anemia, leukopenia, and potentially psychosis. Oral ulcers and synovitis are also common.

diagnoses.name: Lymphoma
diagnoses.rationale: Certain types of lymphoma can cause a wide array of symptoms including hemolytic anemia, leukopenia, and oral ulcers. B symptoms may mimic psychosis, and synovitis can occur due to bone marrow infiltration or paraneoplastic inflammation.

diagnoses.name: Drug-induced Lupus Erythematosus
diagnoses.rationale: Certain medications can induce lupus-like symptoms including psychosis, hemolytic anemia, synovitis, leukopenia, and oral ulcers, similar to systemic lupus erythematosus but typically resolving on discontinuation of the offending drug.
